Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Novel Electric Field Encephalography Sensors for Neuromonitoring
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is development of a new neuroelectric sensor (NeuroDot) for brain monitoring that will measure electric fields generated by brain activity using a new technique termed Electric field Encephalography (EFEG) with best-in-class sensitivity. The EFEG brain monitoring technique is a new modality that has several advantages over the current modalities, electroencephalography EEG (which measures the electric potential on the scalp) and magnetoencephalography MEG (which measures the magnetic field). The NeuroDot brain sensors are quickly mountable and demountable and enable 24/7 neuromonitoring with wireless connectivity to smartphones and wearable technologies like smartwatches. The NeuroDot sensors provide neurological data analyzed with subsequent software post-processing to provide information on the activity of the brain for analysis of the mental health state. Some of the immediate areas of impact of the EFEG technology based NeuroDot sensors include functional brain imaging at high temporal and spatial resolution to enable localization of epileptic seizures, and understanding of pattern recognition and cognition by the brain. The signals from these sensors will provide insights into mental conditions related to aging, sleep, epilepsy and neurological disorders. The high performance NeuroDot sensors will also be usable for human-machine and brain-computer interfaces.

This proposed project will improve and optimize the current NeuroDot prototype to create marketable products that meet specifications for real-time neuromonitoring. This project will achieve its aims through the following Goals. Goal 1: Optimize the wireless NeuroDot sensor to meet metrics and milestones for real-time neuromonitoring. Goal 2: Perform Usability Testing and Sensor Performance Benchmarking through studies on human subjects. The project will develop breakthrough nanodendritic electrodes and wireless technologies for the NeuroDot sensor for long-term low noise EFEG recordings in a compact (< 1square cm) form factor. The critical research tasks involve the characterization of the sensor performance including standard metrics pertaining to sensitivity and noise immunity - signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and common-mode rejection ratio (CMMR) - as well as robustness to common artifacts afflicting other neuroelectric measurement modalities (e.g., electrode movement, jaw and ocular movements, baseline drift). Specific benchmarks of NeuroDot performance in terms of signal-to-noise ratio, wireless connectivity, battery life and signal quality will be assessed. The human subjects tests will provide benchmarks for neuromonitoring performance in terms of parameters like information bit rate, speed of stimulus response, measurement of visually evoked potential, spectral content of brain activity and classification accuracy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this Phase I SBIR project NeuroFieldz Inc. and Northeastern University aimed to develop NeuroDotTM a new sensor that will measure electric fields and potential generated by brain activity in a new modality of neuromonitoring termed Electric Field Encephalography (EFEG).  Designed using biomimetic principles employed by sharks, the NeuroDot sensor to measure scalp electric fields (and potentials) is a platform technology with small footprint, high sensitivity that is cyber-integrated with laptop connectivity for continuous monitoring. The principal goals of this Phase I SBIR project were: 

Goal 1: Optimize the wireless NeuroDot sensor.

Goal 2: Usability Testing and Sensor Performance Benchmarking.

The Phase I SBIR projects met its key goals and metrics and went well beyond them in several instances. A wireless NeuroDot sensor was demonstrated comprised of a mechanically robust single sensor platform (with future extensibility) that consists of the head-mounted wireless transmitting remote device and a base station wireless receiving device that plugs into a desktop or laptop computer in order to stream data in real time to a display and recording program (Fig 1).  The NeuroDot sensor was demonstrated to operate in both EFEG and conventional EEG modes (first of its kind), with almost instantaneous ease of setup.

Usability studies on human subjects were carried out and show that the NeuroDot is well configured for rapid use in office settings, and displayed superior performance for several benchmark metrics compared with other similar devices.

The work led to the following breakthroughs: 

Breakthrough #1: Proprietary nanodendritic dry electrodes with low noise performance and high repeatability were developed and used. Repeatable results were obtained over dozens of mounting/demounting usages with minimal maintenance. We believe there are no comparable electrodes on the market today. 

Breakthrough #2: NeuroDot setup time is near instantaneous (place on head and start recording, < 2 mins), addressing a key pain point with current sensors. No scalp preparation or use of gels or pastes required.  Built-in impedance measurement allows for signal quality assurance if adjustment is needed. 

Breakthrough #3: The NeuroDot provides clean EFEG and EEG recordings, with very high signal to noise ratio (Fig 2) . This dual modality enables comparison to standard EEG signals well-known to clinicians, while enable new ultra-high sensitivity EFEG measurements. Benchmark data for Berger effect ratio (Fig 3) and Visual Evoked Potentials (VEP) show 4 - 10X improvements over competing EEG sensors (Fig 4-6).  

Breakthrough #4: The NeuroDot sensor was used to measure brain response to several visual stimuli. EFEG outperforms EEG for benchmark metrics like steady-state VEP (ssVEP) signal to noise ratio (Fig 4), pattern reversal tVEP (Fig 5) and Binary Choice SSVEP > 3-4X (Fig 6).

The NeuroDot system is a new best-in-class brain signal measurement system that is cost-effective and portable. The successful completion of this Phase I project has laid the groundwork for a Phase II proposal that will be submitted.

The Phase I SBIR project demonstrated that

  1. Demonstrated the feasibility of the NeuroDot sensor as a high performance, portable brain monitor,
  2. Demonstrated the validity of the EFEG modality, and its superiority in several metrics,
  3. Established the ease of use of the NeuroDot sensor due to the breakthrough nanodendritic electrodes that were developed under this project,
  4. Demonstrated the high quality of the NeuroDot sensor in terms of metrics such as alpha power, Berger effect, noise floor and others,
  5. Demonstrated the high quality response to visual evoked potentials that can be used for several commercial applications.

Even in its present form, the NeuroDot is ready for clinical use for testing patients for various neurological conditions such as multiple sclerosis, optical neuritis, and many others associated with disorders of visual pathways, and will outperform available commercial systems.

The project provided training and professional development in neurotechnology, electronics hardware, and software programming for 8 professionals and STEM students. New devices and tools were developed that will be available to customers in laboratories and clinics. Both NeuroFieldz Inc and Northeastern University developed their infrastructure in neurotechnology under this project.

The NeuroDot EFEG sensor will have broad impact on neuroscience and neurology research, medical and consumer applications. It will catalyze new avenues of neuroscience research by serving existing researchers and also drawing in new researchers globally. In addition to advancing the knowledge base in neuroscience, we anticipate that the advantages of EFEG will have significant impact on detecting and analyzing a wide range of neurological conditions, as well as for assistive applications.

The NeuroFieldz technology will  reduce need for invasive seizure localization monitoring, enhance functional non-invasive mapping, and improve routine monitoring and analysis of epileptiforms. Improved precision in functional brain mapping will lead to advances in understanding brain connectivity, which is important in Traumatic Brain Injury and in various neurodegenerative brain disorders. High quality data in response to various stimuli will provide new insights and diagnostic capabilities for visual, auditory and nerve diseases.
